questions.prompt: A validated alert shows malware on an HMI with no outage. What is the correct initial action for the Incident Commander?
options: Shut down the HMI immediately
Classify the event, timestamp it, and notify SOC/IMT per the communication matrix
Wait for more alerts before acting
Call the vendor for guidance
feedback: Unplanned shutdown can increase impact and lose evidence.
Correct—classification, timestamps, and communications drive the rest of the workflow.
Waiting risks missing escalation and reporting windows.
Vendor outreach happens after internal validation and declarations.

questions.prompt: Which statement best describes when DOE-417 reporting must be started?
options: Only if the utility loses power
Within 1 hour for reportable incidents; by end of next business day for attempts to compromise
Only after the incident is fully closed
Only if an auditor asks for it
feedback: Loss of power is not the only trigger.
Correct—follow CIP-008 reporting timelines for incidents and attempts.
Waiting until closure misses required deadlines.
Reporting is required based on criteria, not auditor request.

questions.prompt: During containment the Technical Responder isolated a server. What should happen before returning it to production?
options: Immediate return to service once the alarm stops
Validation scans, credential resets if needed, and leadership approval to go live
Wait for a vendor recommendation only
No additional steps are required
feedback: Alarms clearing does not equal clean systems.
Correct—validate, document, and obtain approval prior to returning to service.
Vendors support but do not replace validation and approvals.
Recovery evidence is required before going live.

questions.prompt: Which action keeps evidence defensible for compliance?
options: Saving screenshots in personal folders
Documenting chain-of-custody with hashes and storage locations
Waiting to collect evidence until after recovery
Relying on verbal updates
feedback: Personal folders lack traceability.
Correct—documented hashes and locations prove integrity.
Waiting risks evidence loss and audit gaps.
Verbal updates are not auditable.

questions.prompt: General Staff reports a phishing email they did not click. What is the right response?
options: Delete it and move on
Report to SOC/supervisor with details and leave the email intact
Forward it to friends as a warning
Ignore it because no link was clicked
feedback: Deleting removes evidence.
Correct—report quickly, preserve the evidence, and follow instructions.
Forwarding expands exposure and loses control.
Unreported attempts erode situational awareness and compliance.

questions.prompt: After containment and recovery, what should the team do to close the lifecycle?
options: Resume operations without notes
Conduct lessons learned, update the CSIR Plan if needed, and log corrective actions
Rely on memory for future improvements
Wait for the next audit to review
feedback: Closing without reflection loses improvement opportunities.
Correct—document lessons, plan updates, and validation of fixes (CIP-008 R3).
Memory is insufficient for compliance evidence.
Waiting for audits delays remediation and documentation.
